repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - On-Farm and Command Water
            Management and Irrigation Systems Rehabilitation Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
This report evaluates the On-Farm and
            Command Water Management and Irrigation Systems
            Rehabilitation Projects for Pakistan. The four projects were
            a successful part of the early implementation of the RAP
            strategy. However, they drifted away from this strategy and
            did not achieve their projected results and impact. While
            the projects had some worthwhile and widespread poverty
            alleviation impact, they also provided large transfers of
            public resources to some of the rural elite. The
            institutional outcomes of the projects were not up to
            expectations. While the sustainability of the improvements
            made to watercourses under the projects is not in doubt, the
            method of financing adopted, with its heavy reliance on
            external aid and subsidies, is not sustainable. Even so, the
            four projects were generally successful in achieving their
            main physical objectives but the greater institutional and
            social problems affecting system performance remain and may
            have increased. Two major lessons can be learned from these
            projects. First, there is a need for disaggregated
            investment packages which are tailored closely to the
            specific physical, social, and economic characteristics of
            the very different areas within the system instead of broad
            scale national projects. Lastly, there is a need for an
            improved and independent analytical base on water sector
            issues, routinely maintained in current status rather than
            being periodically updated.

repnme.cdata!: Pakistan - On Farm Water Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the On Farm Water
            Management Project for Pakistan was successful. The physical
            targets were achieved, sustainability is likely under
            certain conditions, the impact of the project has been
            substantial on the farming industry, and both the Bank and
            the Borrower performed satisfactorily. There is one central
            lesson learned from this project. It provided the
            opportunity to consolidate the gains achieved under earlier
            projects and to make necessary changes in the program to
            efficiently translate water savings into increased
            agricultural production, improve maintenance of renovated
            watercourses, and emphasize a broader range of OFWM
            practices. New changes to be introduced because of the
            project are: 1) implementation of a pilot program; 2)
            provision of specialized staff training and improved
            coordination between Water Management and Extension; 3)
            provision of an additional Water Management officer and two
            assistants per field team; 4) better project monitoring and
            evaluation; and 5) measures to partially recover the cost of
            construction materials along with rate increases.

repnme.cdata!: Pakistan - On Farm Water Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The On-Farm Water Management Project
            seeks to increase agricultural production by increasing the
            availability and efficient utilization of irrigation water
            at the farm level through improved water management
            practices. The project will include: (i) major renovations
            to about 2,000 watercourses and heavy cleaning of and minor
            improvements to about 16,500 other watercourses; (ii)
            precision land leveling on about 37,000 ac; (iii)
            demonstration plots; (iv) training of On-Farm Water
            Management (OFWM) and Extension Service personnel and Water
            Users Associations (WUA) officials; and (v) supervision and
            administration including technical assistance in the form of
            local supervisory consultants and expatriate experts.
